Welcome to The Hermetic Flight: Where Aerial Arts Meet Tarot Divination

Discover how suspended bodies in motion reveal tarot's archetypal truths. An introduction to The Hermetic Flight Aerial Tarot Deck and the philosophy behind combining aerial performance with divination practice.

Between earth and sky, in that suspended moment where gravity releases its hold and possibility expands, we find ourselves in the same liminal space that tarot divination has always occupied—the threshold between question and answer, between the mundane and the mystical, between who we are and who we're becoming.

This is where **The Hermetic Flight** was born.

After years of development, collaboration with 21 professional aerial performers, and countless hours of intentional choreography, we're approaching the launch of something unprecedented in the tarot community: a fully realized 78-card deck where every image captures real humans defying gravity to embody archetypal energy.

But this isn't just another photographic tarot deck. This is a response to something deeper—a recognition that the transformative journey of the aerial artist *is* the archetypal journey of tarot divination itself.

## Why Aerial Arts and Tarot Belong Together

If you've ever watched an aerial performer suspended twenty feet in the air, trusting nothing but fabric, apparatus, and years of training to hold them aloft, you've witnessed something profound: the physical manifestation of surrender, trust, and transformation that every tarot reading asks of us.

**Aerial arts and tarot divination share the same fundamental truth: growth happens in the space between.**

Between inhale and exhale. Between earth and sky. Between the card you hoped to pull and the card that actually appeared. Between the person you were when you asked the question and the person you'll become after integrating the answer.

Traditional tarot decks—beautiful as they are—show us snapshots. A figure standing with a wand. A person sitting beneath swords. These images capture moments, but aerial performance captures *movement*. And movement is where transformation actually happens.

When you see The High Priestess suspended in an aerial pose, you're not just seeing a static representation of intuitive wisdom—you're witnessing the active practice of trust that accessing intuition requires. When The Hanged Man inverts in silks, you're not just understanding perspective shift intellectually—you're seeing a body literally reorient its relationship to gravity and earth.

This is embodied divination. This is tarot that moves.

## The Problem We're Solving

Here's something most tarot creators don't talk about: **learning tarot is unnecessarily hard**.

Not because the archetypes are complex—humans have been navigating these universal patterns since we first told stories around fires. Tarot is hard because we've created systems that prioritize memorization over intuition, rules over resonance, and "correct" interpretations over personal truth.

The feedback from the tarot community is consistent and loud:

- "I can't memorize 78 cards—it's overwhelming and I keep giving up"
- "Court cards make no sense to me even after years of study"
- "Every teacher contradicts the last one about reversals/spreads/meanings"
- "The guidebook that came with my deck is useless—just generic keywords"
- "I can't read for myself without my emotions clouding everything"
- "How do I know if I'm 'doing it right' when there are so many different approaches?"

We've heard these frustrations echoed across thousands of Reddit discussions, tarot forums, and student testimonials. The Hermetic Flight was designed with these specific challenges in mind.

### Visual Storytelling Replaces Memorization

When you see an aerial performer embodying the Nine of Swords—suspended in a tangle of fabric with their body reflecting the anxious, racing-mind energy of worry—you don't need to memorize "anxiety, nightmares, mental anguish." You *see* it. You *feel* it. The image sticks because it's visceral.

This is how humans actually learn: through story, through body, through image. Not through flash cards and keyword lists.

### Court Cards with Unmistakable Presence

The 16 court cards (Pages, Knights, Queens, Kings) are universally acknowledged as the hardest cards to interpret. Why? Because most decks show similar-looking figures with crowns and swords, leaving readers to puzzle out subtle differences in posture or props.

In aerial tarot, the difference between a Page and a Queen isn't subtle—it's physical. Page energy explores close to the ground, tentative, curious, learning. Queen energy commands space from height, embodied authority, mastery that doesn't need to prove itself. You see the difference in how they hold themselves suspended.

These aren't abstract concepts anymore. They're bodies you can read.

### RWS Compatibility Meets Fresh Perspective

We haven't reinvented the wheel or renamed the Major Arcana (looking at you, decks that call Death "Transformation" and The Tower "Disruption"). The Hermetic Flight honors Rider-Waite-Smith symbolism—the foundation that 90% of tarot resources reference—while adding layers of meaning through aerial arts metaphor.

If you're already familiar with traditional tarot, you'll recognize the archetypal structures immediately. If you're brand new, you can use any RWS-based resource to supplement your learning. We're building on tradition, not abandoning it.

## What Makes This Different From Other Decks

The tarot market is saturated. Beautiful decks launch on Kickstarter weekly. So why does The Hermetic Flight matter?

### 1. Intentional Choreography, Not Posed Photography

Every card in this deck was choreographed specifically to embody its archetype. These aren't performers randomly arranged in pretty shapes—they're aerial artists who studied the card meanings, collaborated on movement choices, and physically embodied the energy we needed to capture.

The performer who became The Hermit spent time in that suspended solitude, finding the quality of intentional withdrawal and inner focus. The performer who became The Tower worked with us to capture that moment of necessary destruction, that precipice before the fall.

This is method acting applied to tarot. This is divination through deliberate embodiment.

### 2. Real Bodies, Real Humans, Real Experience

In an era of AI-generated art flooding the tarot market, The Hermetic Flight is defiantly, proudly, entirely human-created. Every image features a real person—compensated fairly, credited in the guidebook, retaining rights to their images.

These are professional aerial artists from the Pacific Northwest community who brought their own experiences of transformation, fear, trust, and transcendence to these cards. You're not looking at digital approximations of human experience—you're looking at actual humans who know what it means to trust, to fall, to fly.

### 3. Diversity That Reflects Reality

Aerial arts communities are genuinely diverse. People of all body types, ages, ethnicities, and backgrounds take to the air. The Hermetic Flight documents that reality.

You'll see performers in their 20s and performers in their 50s. You'll see different body types successfully executing advanced skills. You'll see diverse skin tones and gender presentations. This isn't tokenism—this is documentation of the actual community that made this deck possible.

If you've ever felt like tarot imagery didn't include someone who looks like you, we hope you'll find yourself reflected here.

### 4. Premium Quality Built for Daily Use

We researched what the tarot community actually complains about regarding deck quality. The feedback was specific:

- **Oversized cards hurt hands and are hard to shuffle** → We chose standard 2.75" x 4.75" sizing
- **Thin, flimsy card stock feels cheap and doesn't last** → We're using 300-350 GSM premium stock
- **Slick coating makes cards "shoot off into space" when shuffling** → Matte linen finish prevents this
- **Guidebooks are generic and useless** → Comprehensive companion book with deck-specific meanings, performer stories, and original spreads
- **Packaging falls apart immediately** → Rigid box with magnetic closure built to survive years of use

This deck is designed to be used, not just collected. We want you reading with it daily, not afraid to handle it.

### 5. A Guidebook That Actually Guides

Our companion guidebook goes far beyond standard "Little White Books":

- **Deck-specific interpretations** explaining why we chose particular aerial poses and apparatus for each card
- **Personal stories** from the creator and performers about their relationships with these archetypes
- **Both upright and reversed meanings** (with permission to ignore reversals if that's not your style)
- **Original spreads** designed specifically for the deck
- **Structured learning path** for beginners that doesn't overwhelm
- **Court card mastery section** with decision trees for determining interpretations
- **Tips for reading objectively for yourself** addressing self-reading challenges
- **Behind-the-scenes stories** from the photoshoots and choreography process

This is a teaching tool, not just a reference pamphlet.

## Who This Deck Is For

**You're a complete beginner** who's been intimidated by tarot's 78-card learning curve and wants a deck with imagery that speaks clearly without requiring memorization.

**You're an experienced reader** looking for fresh perspective on cards you thought you knew completely, and you're drawn to the physicality of embodied archetypes.

**You're an aerial artist or movement practitioner** who recognizes the spiritual dimensions of your practice and wants a divination tool that honors that connection.

**You're tired of generic decks** that could be for anyone, and you want something with specific artistic vision and intentional creation behind every image.

**You're building a professional tarot reading practice** and want a premium tool that justifies premium pricing while offering unique talking points with clients.

**You're drawn to the combination** of ancient archetypal wisdom with contemporary performance art and you want to see what happens at that intersection.

## The Invitation

Tarot divination isn't fortune-telling. It's not about predicting a fixed future or receiving messages from external forces (though if that's your framework, there's room for you here too).

At its core, tarot is about **creating space for reflection**. It's about using archetypal imagery to unlock perspectives you already possess but haven't consciously accessed. It's about asking better questions and sitting with complex answers. It's about recognizing patterns and possibilities.

And sometimes, it's about seeing a human body suspended in silk, trusting absolutely in their apparatus and training, and recognizing that same quality of trust being asked of you in your reading.

The Hermetic Flight exists because we believe tarot can be more accessible, more embodied, more visually compelling, and more intuitive than current options offer. We believe learning shouldn't require memorization. We believe imagery should tell clear stories. We believe quality matters. And we believe the intersection of aerial arts and tarot divination reveals something neither practice shows alone.

**Between earth and sky, between question and answer, between who you are and who you're becoming—this is where we find our truth in suspension.**

Welcome to The Hermetic Flight. We're honored you're here.

What's included in the companion guidebook?

Our comprehensive guidebook goes far beyond standard "Little White Books":

For each card:

  • Detailed description of the aerial imagery and symbolism
  • Upright interpretation with deck-specific context
  • Reversed interpretation (optional use)
  • Keywords for quick reference
  • Questions for reflection
  • How this card commonly appears in readings

Additional content:

  • Introduction to aerial arts symbolism
  • Structured learning path for beginners
  • Guide to reading for yourself objectively
  • Court card mastery section
  • 10+ original spreads designed for the deck
  • Tips for connecting cards into coherent narratives
  • Stories from the creation process and performer interviews
  • Suit system and elemental correspondences
  • Care instructions for your deck

The guidebook is written in clear, accessible language—not dense esoteric jargon—making it valuable for beginners while offering depth for experienced readers.
Will the guidebook explain why you chose specific aerial poses?

Yes! Each card description explains the intentional choreography choices and how they relate to traditional tarot symbolism. For example, you'll understand why a specific inversion, suspension point, or fabric configuration was chosen to embody that card's energy.

This behind-the-scenes insight helps you understand not just what the card means, but why this particular image captures that meaning—deepening your reading practice.

Standard tarot size: 2.75" x 4.75" (70mm x 120mm). This is the most popular size because it:

  • Fits comfortably in average-sized hands
  • Shuffles easily without strain
  • Fits standard tarot bags and boxes
  • Doesn't "shoot off into space" when handling

We specifically avoided oversized formats after research showed they create significant usability frustration, particularly for readers with smaller hands or joint issues.
What card stock and finish will you use?

Premium 300-350 GSM card stock with a matte linen finish. This combination provides:

  • Substantial feel without excessive stiffness
  • Smooth shuffling without cards sticking together or flying apart
  • Durability for daily use
  • Matte finish that reduces glare and fingerprints
  • No sharp edges that cause paper cuts

The cards will arrive pre-conditioned for immediate use—no breaking-in period required.
Will the card backs be reversible or directional?

Fully reversible. The back design reads identically from either direction, so you can't tell if a card is reversed before flipping it. This supports all reading styles, whether you use reversals or not.
What kind of packaging does it come with?

The deck includes a rigid box with magnetic closure—significantly more durable than standard paperboard packaging. This protects your investment through:

  • Multiple openings/closings without wear
  • Protection when traveling
  • Secure storage preventing card damage
  • Premium feel matching deck quality

Stretch goals may include fabric storage pouches and travel tins for backers who want additional protection options.
Will there be a pocket or mini edition?

Potentially as a stretch goal! We're tracking community interest in a travel-sized version (approximately 2.25" x 3.75"). If you'd like to see this option, let us know in comments or through our newsletter feedback.
What makes The Hermetic Flight Aerial Tarot Deck different from other tarot decks?

The Hermetic Flight combines the transformative art of aerial performance with traditional tarot symbolism in a way no deck has done before. Each card features real aerial artists captured in movement, creating a living embodiment of tarot archetypes. Unlike generic photographic decks, our imagery is intentionally choreographed to reflect traditional Rider-Waite-Smith symbolism while introducing fresh visual metaphors through bodies suspended in air—representing the liminal space where divination happens.

Key differentiators include 21 professional aerial performers, 100% human-created photography, and fully illustrated Minor Arcana cards.
Is this deck suitable for beginners?

Absolutely. The Hermetic Flight was designed with beginners in mind while remaining valuable for experienced readers. The aerial imagery provides intuitive visual stories that help new readers understand card meanings without pure memorization.
Will this deck work if I'm already familiar with Rider-Waite-Smith?
Yes! The Hermetic Flight honors traditional RWS symbolism while introducing aerial metaphors that deepen familiar meanings. If you know RWS, you'll immediately recognize the archetypal structures.
I'm completely new to tarot. Where do I start?

Start simple and build gradually:

  • Begin with daily single-card pulls - Pull one card each morning and reflect on how its energy shows up in your day
  • Focus on the imagery first - What do you see? What emotions does it evoke? Trust your initial impressions
  • Then reference the guidebook - Compare your intuitive read with traditional meanings
  • Journal your interpretations - Track how your understanding evolves

Don't try to memorize all 78 cards at once. Our guidebook includes a structured learning path that introduces cards in manageable groups, starting with the Major Arcana's 22 cards before moving to the suits.
Do I need to be "psychic" or "intuitive" to read tarot?

No. While some readers incorporate psychic abilities, tarot works equally well as a psychological tool, creative prompt, or decision-making framework. The cards create a structured space for reflection—the insight comes from your own wisdom, not supernatural ability.

Many successful tarot readers approach the practice completely secularly, using the archetypal imagery to unlock perspectives they already possess but haven't consciously accessed.
How long does it take to learn tarot divination?

You can give meaningful readings from day one, even if they're simple. Most people feel comfortable with:

  • Single-card pulls: Immediately
  • Three-card spreads: Within 2-4 weeks
  • Complex spreads: 3-6 months
  • Reading professionally for others: 1-2 years of regular practice

The Hermetic Flight's visual storytelling accelerates this timeline by making card meanings more immediately accessible than text-heavy or abstract decks.
Should I learn reversed card meanings?

That's completely up to you—there's no "right" answer. Some readers use reversals, others don't. Both approaches are valid.

Arguments against learning reversals initially:

  • You're already learning 78 cards; don't double your workload unnecessarily
  • Many professional readers never use reversals and read beautifully
  • You can always add reversals later if desired

Arguments for learning reversals:

  • Adds nuance and depth to readings
  • Helps identify blocked or internalized energy
  • Some spreads benefit from directional indicators

Our guidebook includes reversed meanings for those who want them, but frames them as optional rather than required.
What's the deal with court cards? Everyone says they're confusing.

Court cards (Pages, Knights, Queens, Kings) are notoriously tricky because they can represent:

  • Actual people in your life
  • Aspects of your own personality
  • Situational approaches or energy
  • Messages or stages of development

The Hermetic Flight addresses this confusion through distinct physical embodiment. Each court card features a performer whose presence, movement quality, and energy clearly conveys whether you're encountering:

  • Page energy (curious, learning, grounded exploration)
  • Knight energy (dynamic action, forward momentum)
  • Queen energy (mastery, internal authority)
  • King energy (external authority, established power)

The guidebook includes a dedicated court card section with specific guidance on determining which interpretation applies in context.
Do I need to know anything about aerial arts to use this deck?

Not at all. The deck is designed for tarot readers, not aerial performers. The guidebook explains any aerial-specific concepts needed to understand the imagery, but no prior knowledge is required.

The aerial elements serve as visual metaphors that enhance tarot meanings—suspension represents liminal space, inversions show perspective shifts, and apparatus choices reflect elemental qualities. These connections are intuitive even without aerial experience.
Why combine aerial arts with tarot divination?

Aerial arts and tarot share profound symbolic resonance:

  • Suspension = Liminal Space - Both practices exist between earth and sky, between the conscious and unconscious, between question and answer.
  • Defying Gravity = Transcendence - Aerial performance literally transcends normal physical limitations, just as divination transcends ordinary perception.
  • Trust and Release = Surrender - Both require releasing control to discover what's possible.
  • Physical Embodiment = Grounding Abstract Concepts - Aerial artists physically embody archetypes, making abstract tarot concepts viscerally tangible.
  • Risk and Transformation - Both practices involve calculated risk in service of transformation.

The combination creates a uniquely powerful visual language for tarot divination.
Are all 78 cards photographed with aerial performers?

The 78-card deck features 21 professional aerial artists across multiple cards. Not every single card shows aerial performance—some cards require grounded or environmental imagery—but the aerial aesthetic and symbolism thread throughout the entire deck, creating visual cohesion.

Absolutely not. Every image in The Hermetic Flight is human-created photography featuring real aerial performers. We believe tarot's power comes from authentic human experience and artistic intention—something AI cannot replicate.

All 21 performers were compensated fairly, credited in the guidebook, and retained rights to their images. This is a collaborative human creative project from start to finish.
What kind of diversity is represented in the deck?

The Hermetic Flight intentionally features diverse representation across:

  • Body types and sizes (aerial arts welcomes all bodies)
  • Ages (from 20s through 50s+)
  • Ethnicities and skin tones
  • Gender presentations
  • Abilities

This wasn't tokenistic—aerial communities are genuinely diverse, and we documented that reality. Tarot speaks to all humans; the imagery should reflect that.
Did you rename any Major Arcana cards?

No. All Major Arcana retain their traditional names (The Fool, The Magician, The High Priestess, etc.). We believe radical renaming creates unnecessary confusion and can indicate an oracle deck rather than a true tarot deck.

However, our interpretations honor both traditional and modern understandings—for example, The Devil addresses both shadow work and systemic oppression, and Death explores transformation beyond the individual level.

Potentially in the future, but not as part of the initial Kickstarter. We're focused on delivering an exceptional physical deck first. If there's significant community interest in a digital companion (for journaling, learning, or virtual readings), we may explore that in a later phase.

Can I use this deck for professional readings with clients?

Absolutely! The Hermetic Flight is suitable for professional use. The premium quality, clear imagery, and comprehensive guidebook make it excellent for:

  • In-person readings
  • Video chat/online readings
  • Workshop teaching
  • Photography for your marketing materials (with credit)

Professional readers backing at higher tiers will receive multiple decks at reduced pricing.
Can I read tarot for myself, or do I need to see a professional reader?

You can absolutely read for yourself! While reading for yourself presents objectivity challenges (emotional investment in outcomes can cloud interpretation), millions of people maintain successful self-reading practices.

Our guidebook includes specific techniques for reading objectively for yourself:

  • Using clarifier cards when confused
  • Journaling before and after readings
  • Setting clear intentions before shuffling
  • Waiting 24-48 hours before rereading on emotional topics
  • Treating yourself like a client you're reading for

Self-reading is also more affordable, private, and convenient than regular professional sessions.
How do I know if my tarot reading is accurate?

Tarot isn't fortune-telling—it's reflection, pattern recognition, and intuitive synthesis. "Accuracy" isn't about prediction but about resonance:

A valuable reading:

  • Provides new perspective on your situation
  • Resonates emotionally even if intellectually challenging
  • Offers actionable insight
  • Creates clarity where there was confusion
  • Feels neither overly vague nor impossibly specific

A less useful reading:

  • Feels completely disconnected from your situation
  • Uses only generic statements that could apply to anyone
  • Leaves you more confused than when you started
  • Makes you feel anxious without offering constructive guidance

The cards reveal patterns and possibilities, not fixed futures. Your free will always determines outcomes.
What if I pull "scary" cards like Death, The Tower, or The Devil?

These cards have unfairly frightening reputations! Understanding their actual meanings eliminates the fear:

  • Death - Transformation, endings that make space for beginnings, shedding what no longer serves you. Rarely literal death.
  • The Tower - Sudden revelation, necessary destruction of false structures, breakthrough after breakdown. Liberation disguised as disaster.
  • The Devil - Recognizing bondage (to addiction, toxic patterns, limiting beliefs), shadow work, reclaiming power from what controls you.

These cards often appear during our most significant growth periods. Our guidebook includes detailed explorations of commonly feared cards, reframing them as powerful allies rather than omens.
How often should I read my cards?

There's no "should"—it's entirely personal. Common practices include:

  • Daily single-card meditation
  • Weekly deeper spreads
  • Monthly overview readings
  • As-needed guidance on specific questions

Warning signs you're overreading:

  • Pulling cards repeatedly on the same question seeking different answers
  • Feeling anxious when you can't read daily
  • Making no decisions without consulting cards first
  • Reading becomes compulsive rather than reflective

If you notice dependency developing, consider taking a break and consulting a therapist or trusted friend about decision-making patterns.

The Hermetic Flight is created by Deirdre Quigley, an aerial arts instructor and Reiki practitioner who recognized the profound symbolic resonance between aerial performance and tarot divination. After years of teaching aerial students to overcome fear and embrace transformation through suspended movement, she realized these were the same journeys tarot guides us through.

The project combines Deirdre's background in:

  • Professional aerial arts instruction
  • Energy healing and intuitive work
  • Tarot reading practice
  • Visual storytelling and creative direction

Her husband Taylor Quigley provided technical production, multi-camera filming, and post-processing expertise through Quigley Multimedia.

All 21 performers are professional or advanced aerial artists from the Pacific Northwest aerial community. They were selected to represent:

  • Diverse body types, ages, and backgrounds
  • Specific movement qualities matching card archetypes
  • Willingness to collaborate on choreographed embodiment
  • Ability to physically execute required poses safely

Performers were compensated, credited, and maintain image rights. Many are excited to share how they personally connect with the cards they embody.
What's the story behind the project name?

"The Hermetic Flight" references:

  • Hermetic tradition - Esoteric wisdom, "as above, so below"
  • Hermes/Mercury - Messenger between worlds, traveler of liminal spaces
  • Flight - Aerial arts, transcendence, movement between realms

The title captures both the tarot's hermetic philosophical roots and the literal flight of aerial performance.
